author: By Kayla Guo
title: Pelosi Wants F.B.I. to Investigate Pro-Palestinian Protesters
description: The former House speaker suggested without offering evidence that some protesters calling for a cease-fire in Gaza had financial ties to Russia and Vladimir V. Putin.
content: Representative Nancy Pelosi, Democrat of California and the former House speaker, on Sunday called for the F.B.I. to investigate protesters demanding a cease-fire in the Israel-Hamas conflict, suggesting without evidence that some activists may have ties to Russia and President Vladimir V. Putin.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sam Corbin
title: Relating to the Bottom Layer
description: Garrett Chalfin and Andrew Kingsley give us inside information.
content: Jump to: Today’s Theme | Tricky Clues
source.name: The New York Times

author: By RonNell Andersen Jones
title: The E. Jean Carroll Verdict Exposes the Limits of Libel Law
description: Incentives to serve up lies for politics or profit are so strong that libel damage awards and settlements may not meaningfully change behaviors.
content: In the days since a New York jury ordered Donald Trump to pay $83.3 million in damages to the libel plaintiff E. Jean Carroll, the question has been whether the dollar amount was high enough to put a stop to his lies.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Katherine Miller
title: Nikki Haley Isn’t Going Anywhere
description: The brightness of Haley’s past few days underscores the darkness of Trump’s.
content: What is Nikki Haley doing? What are her real intentions? Those questions have dominated every aspect of her candidacy.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Frances Robles
title: After Help From Kenyan Police Is Blocked, Haitians Ask: What Now?
description: As Haiti sank into gang-dominated chaos, Kenya promised to send officers to pacify the streets. Now a court has rejected that plan, and there does not seem to be another.
content: Gangs have taken over entire neighborhoods in Haiti’s capital, and killings have more than doubled in the past year, but for the organizers of the Port-au-Prince Jazz Festival, the show simply had to go on.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Peter Baker
title: Talks in Paris will focus on a hostage deal that could pause the fighting in Gaza.
description: American-led negotiators are edging closer to an agreement in which Israel would suspend its war in Gaza for about two months in exchange for the release of more than 100 hostages still held by Hamas, a deal that could be sealed in the next two weeks and will be the subject of talks in Paris on Sunday.
content: American-led negotiators are edging closer to an agreement in which Israel would suspend its war in Gaza for about two months in exchange for the release of more than 100 hostages still held by Hamas, a deal that could be sealed in the next two weeks and will be the subject of talks in Paris on Sunday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kate Zernike
title: The Campus Wars Aren’t About Gender … Are They?
description: Recent Ivy League dramas have made women leaders in academia wonder how far they’ve really come.
content: In the first weeks of the war between Israel and Hamas, Nancy Andrews read about American college presidents under fire and something nagged at her.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Is the Trump Threat Too Serious for Humor?
description: Readers discuss an Opinion guest essay that urges an end to Trump jokes and mockery. Also: Jan. 6; China’s birthrates; debating the Mideast war.
content: To the Editor:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Isabel Kershner
title: Israel Moves to Block Protesters From Preventing Flow of Aid into Gaza
description: The Israeli military has declared the area around the Kerem Shalom border crossing a closed military zone.
content: Israel on Sunday stepped up efforts to prevent Israeli protesters from blocking the flow of aid into Gaza, two days after the United Nations’ highest court said it must allow more supplies to get into the enclave.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jacob N. Shapiro and Chris Mattmann
title: A.I. Is Coming for the Past, Too
description: In our focus on protecting the present and future from A.I., we have forgotten about the urgent need to protect the past.
content: We don’t have to imagine a world where deepfakes can so believably imitate the voices of politicians that they can be used to gin up scandals that could sway elections. It’s already here. Fortunately, there are numerous reasons for optimism about society’s ability to identify fake media and maintain a shared understanding of current events
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Roger Cohen
title: Protesters Hurl Soup at the Mona Lisa
description: Two women from an environmental group threw pumpkin-colored soup at the artwork, which is behind bulletproof glass at the Louvre and did not appear to sustain damage.
content: Two protesters from an environmental group hurled pumpkin-colored soup on the Mona Lisa at the Louvre museum in Paris on Sunday, splashing the bulletproof glass that protects the most famous painting in the world, but not apparently damaging the work itself.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maria Abi-Habib and Sheera Frenkel
title: Where Is Hamas Getting Its Weapons? Increasingly, From Israel.
description: The very weapons that Israeli forces have used to enforce a blockade of Gaza are now being used against them.
content: Israeli military and intelligence officials have concluded that a significant number of weapons used by Hamas in the Oct. 7 attacks and in the war in Gaza came from an unlikely source: the Israeli military itself.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Constant Méheut and Thomas Gibbons-Neff
title: After Two Years of Bloody Fighting, Ukraine Wrestles With Conscription
description: A proposed bill on mobilization has become the focus of a debate as more men dodge the draft and calls rise to demobilize exhausted soldiers.
content: When Russian troops and tanks invaded Ukraine in February 2022, tens of thousands of Ukrainians rushed to serve in the army in a surge of patriotic fervor. The influx of fighters who dutifully answered their draft notices or enlisted as volunteers helped to repel Russia’s initial assault and thwart the Kremlin’s plans to decapitate the Ukrainian government.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By New York Times Games
title: Spelling Bee Forum
description: Feeling stuck on today’s puzzle? We can help.
content: Hi busy bees! Welcome to today’s Spelling Bee forum. There are a number of terms that appear in both this article and other online discussions of the Spelling Bee; a glossary of those terms compiled by Monicat, a Times reader, can be found below.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Zolan Kanno-Youngs
title: In South Carolina, Biden Tries to Persuade Black Voters to Reject Trump
description: President Biden sought to energize his base in the state that propelled him to the White House, but some local leaders said he needed to do more to highlight his achievements.
content: Hoping to revitalize the momentum that propelled him to the White House, President Biden told a largely Black audience on Saturday night that “you’re the reason Donald Trump is a defeated former president,” in what was effectively his first appearance related to the Democratic primaries.
source.name: The New York Times

title: ‘We Arranged to Meet Near Her Apartment on Second Avenue’
description: A book critic passes by, a leaky canoe off Bergen Beach and more reader tales of New York City in this week’s Metropolitan Diary.
content: Dear Diary:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alex Traub
title: Marlena Shaw, Venerable Nightclub Chanteuse, Dies at 84
description: She sang jazz (with Count Basie, among others) and later funk and disco, frequently in intimate venues, where she regaled audiences with tales of old love affairs.
content: Marlena Shaw, who cultivated a sultry stage presence and husky voice from the final echoes of the big-band era, to the go-go Playboy Clubs of the 1960s, to the rise of funk, to disco and finally to the modern cabaret circuit, died on Jan. 19. She was 84.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emma Dibdin
title: 5 Podcasts for Hollywood’s Awards Season
description: As Oscars night approaches, these shows offer expert analysis and predictions, insight into behind-the-scenes machinations and reflections on front-runners of the past.
content: The 2024 awards season has felt unusually hectic so far, thanks to the strike-delayed Emmy Awards shifting from their usual fall airdate to January. To help make sense of it all — and unpack the discombobulated state of Hollywood now — these five podcasts offer a mixture of expert analysis and predictions for the major ceremonies, original reporting on the industry trends and behind-the-scenes machinations that influence voting, and reflections on Oscar front-runners of the past that probably shouldn’t have been.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Anna Betts and Alex Lemonides
title: In 100 Victims of the Lahaina Fire, Legacies That Live On
description: Authorities have identified the last known person to have died in the wildfire. Young and old, those lost won’t be forgotten.
content: Terri Thomas was a beloved aunt who loved outdoor adventures. Po’omaika’i Estores-Losano, a musician and father, was trying to rebuild his life. Tony Takafua, 7 years old, had barely begun his.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lydia Polgreen
title: If We Want to Live in a World With Rules, They Have to Apply to Israel, Too
description: Whatever the eventual outcome of the genocide case, it sets up an epic battle over the meaning and values of the so-called rules-based order.
content: Over the past month, we’ve watched an astonishing, high-stakes global drama play out in The Hague. A group of countries from the poorer, less powerful bloc some call the global south, led by South Africa, dragged the government of Israel and, by extension, its rich, powerful allies into the top court of the Western rules-based order and accused Israel of prosecuting a brutal war in Gaza that is “genocidal in character.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Simbarashe Cha
title: Street Style Levels Up to Couture
description: Zendaya debuted drama, Jennifer Lopez made an entrance, but style on the street was just as bold.
content: Couture week is by no means an outlier on the fashion calendar. It is, after all, where designers are expected to flex a bit of imaginative muscle, dare to be creative outside the margins and show what artistry looks like at the height of this medium.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ellen Barry
title: The Man in Room 117
description: Andrey Shevelyov would rather live on the street than take antipsychotic medication. Should it be his decision to make?
content: Alone with his mother for the first time in almost a year, Andrey Shevelyov had a question: Could he come home?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sam Sifton
title: Plush, Perfumed Pepperpot
description: Millie Peartree’s new recipe for this beloved Guyanese stew, rich with spices and savory-sweet cassareep, is just the thing for a winter weekend.
content: Good morning. Time was, a goodly part of my correspondence was with readers annoyed with me or with The New York Times for publishing recipes calling for ingredients unavailable to them, either for reasons of geography or because they didn’t wish to stray beyond the aisles of their local supermarket.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ruth Maclean
title: Three African Juntas Leave Regional Bloc, Accusing It of ‘Inhumane’ Sanctions
description: The sanctions were imposed after soldiers seized power in Mali, Niger and Burkina Faso.
content: Soldiers who seized power in three West African nations announced on Sunday that they would pull their countries out of their regional economic bloc.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maggie Astor
title: Haley Hits Trump on Border and His ‘Rants,’ Saying ‘He Feels Threatened’
description: Nikki Haley, coming off losses in Iowa and New Hampshire, also said she needed to “show momentum” in South Carolina’s Feb. 24 primary, but stopped short of saying she needed to win her home state.
content: Nikki Haley denounced former President Donald J. Trump in an interview on Sunday for his angry responses to his legal losses and suggested that his pressuring of congressional Republicans not to agree to a border-security deal before the election was a purely political ploy.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Aimee Ortiz
title: Statue of Jackie Robinson Stolen From Kansas Park
description: A bronze life-size statue of the baseball player who broke racial barriers in 1947 was cut at its ankles, leaving behind just its shoes and the statue’s base.
content: The authorities in Kansas are searching for the vandals who stole a life-size bronze statue commemorating Jackie Robinson, the first Black Major League Baseball player of the modern era, after they cut it off at the ankles, leaving behind just the statue’s shoes and base.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matthew Mpoke Bigg
title: These Are the Countries That Said They Will Pause Funding to UNRWA
description: The announcements came after Israel accused a dozen employees of the agency that provides aid to Palestinians of participating in the Oct. 7 attacks.
content: Several countries said over the weekend that they would suspend funding for the United Nations agency that provides food, water and other essential services for Palestinian civilians in the Gaza Strip.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ben Protess, Maggie Haberman and Susanne Craig
title: $83 Million Verdict Renews Spotlight on Trump’s Finances
description: The judgment for E. Jean Carroll, and another potentially much larger one on the horizon, could compel the former president to sell some of his assets.
content: He did not go to jail, and has not lost his grip on the race for the Republican presidential nomination, but a jury’s verdict in a civil defamation trial last week nonetheless hit Donald J. Trump where it hurts: his wallet.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Adam Nagourney
title: Trump and Biden Get Ready for the Very Long Haul
description: The 2024 general election campaign is set to be one of the longest in modern history. There will be no spring break.
content: With Donald J. Trump rapidly closing in on the Republican presidential nomination, the 2024 general election campaign is set to be one of the longest in modern history, pushing President Biden and Mr. Trump into unfamiliar territory as they struggle to engage an electorate that seems numbed by the prospect of a 2020 rematch.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Benjamin Weiser
title: Carroll Promises to Do ‘Something Good’ With a Fortune Won From Trump
description: The writer was awarded $83.3 million for his defamation. Now, she will have to figure out how to use it.
content: As soon as E. Jean Carroll heard the verdict on Friday — $83.3 million in defamation damages against Donald J. Trump — a world of possibility opened before her: How to use the money?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Desiree Ibekwe
title: Has Hollywood Lost China?
description: Last year, no American movie broke the Top 10 at the Chinese box office.
content: “Barbenheimer” — the portmanteau given to the same-day release of “Barbie” and “Oppenheimer” last summer — was a genuine cultural phenomenon for much of the world. Cinemas were filled with outfits in various hues of pink. Social media frothed with opinions. And the films brought in a combined $2.3 billion globally.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Carl Hulse
title: As Biden Judicial Confirmations Slow, Senate Gains Ground on Red-State Judges
description: The Democratic majority has made headway in winning confirmation of Biden nominees in G.O.P.-led states, but has fallen behind the pace of the Trump era in the overall push to remake the federal courts.
content: President Biden and Senate Democrats have fallen behind the rapid pace set by Republicans in shaping the federal courts during the Trump era, but they have made fresh headway in advancing judicial nominees in states represented by Republicans.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Robert Pinsky
title: When Language Fails Us and the Moment
description: Plain, direct language remains rare, desirable — and risky in ways that those in authority, even more than the rest of us, try to avoid.
content: A writer I admire expresses in a few words his disdain for plausible but empty political language, beginning with one good example. “The word Fascism,” he writes, “has now no meaning except insofar as it signifies ‘something not desirable.’” He adds other exhausted words, including democracy, freedom and patriotic — convenient terms for establishing righteousness, easily melting into self-righteousness.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mihir Zaveri
title: The Tax Break New York Relied on to Build Housing Is Gone. What’s Next?
description: The tax exemption known as 421a expired in 2022. A fight over its replacement, called 485x, could have major implications for the city’s future.
content: Nearly every debate about New York’s housing crisis involves a state program called “421a.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Safak Timur and Emma Bubola
title: Two Masked Attackers Kill 1 in Shooting at Istanbul Church
description: The Islamic State has taken responsibility for the attack, according to the SITE intelligence group.
content: Two masked gunmen shot and killed a man during a church service on Sunday morning in Istanbul, Turkish officials said, an attack that the Islamic State later took responsibility for.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David French
title: When the Right Ignores Its Sex Scandals
description: The case of the disgraced pastor Paul Pressler offers a window into why America is so divided as a nation.
content: Let me share with you one of the worst and most important recent news stories that you’ve probably never heard about. Late last month, the Southern Baptist Convention settled a sex abuse lawsuit brought against a man named Paul Pressler for an undisclosed sum. The lawsuit was filed in 2017 and alleged that Pressler had raped a man named Duane Rollins for decades, with the rapes beginning when Rollins was only 14 years old.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By New York Times Games
title: Today’s Wordle Review
description: In case you need some puzzle help.
content: Welcome to The Wordle Review. Be warned: This page contains spoilers for today’s puzzle. Solve Wordle first, or scroll at your own risk.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ferris Jabr, Adrienne Hurst, Aaron Esposito, John Woo, Corey Schreppel and Paul Pontious
title: The Sunday Read: ‘The Whale Who Went AWOL’
description: Hvaldimir escaped captivity and became a global celebrity. Now, no one can agree about what to do with him.
content: On April 26, 2019, a beluga whale appeared near Tufjord, a village in northern Norway, immediately alarming fishermen in the area. Belugas in that part of the world typically inhabit the remote Arctic and are rarely spotted as far south as the Norwegian mainland. Although they occasionally travel solo, they tend to live and move in groups. This particular whale was entirely alone and unusually comfortable around humans, trailing boats and opening his mouth as though expecting to be fed.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Karoun Demirjian
title: House Republicans Release Impeachment Charges Against Mayorkas
description: The articles accuse the homeland security secretary of refusing to uphold the law and breaching the public trust in his handling of immigration. A House committee is scheduled to approve them on Tuesday.
content: House Republicans on Sunday released two articles of impeachment against Alejandro N. Mayorkas, the homeland security secretary, charging President Biden’s top immigration official with refusing to uphold the law and breaching the public trust in his handling of a surge of migration at the U.S. border with Mexico.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maya King
title: Black Pastors Pressure Biden to Call for a Cease-Fire in Gaza
description: Black congregants’ dismay at President Biden’s posture on the war could imperil his re-election bid.
content: As the Israel-Hamas war enters its fourth month, a coalition of Black faith leaders is pressuring the Biden administration to push for a cease-fire — a campaign spurred in part by their parishioners, who are increasingly distressed by the suffering of Palestinians and critical of the president’s response to it.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Joseph Bernstein
title: Hark, the Millennial Death Wail
description: The largest living generation in America peers into the abyss of middle age. Are we really worried, or is it just a shtick?
content: There’s a keening sound coming from America’s co-working spaces, third-wave coffee shops, and mommy-and-me yoga classes.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Peter Eavis
title: Since Ohio Train Derailment, Accidents Have Gone Up, Not Down
description: The total number of accidents for the top five freight railroads increased, and Congress still hasn’t passed legislation to prevent similar disasters.
content: After a freight train carrying hazardous chemicals derailed a year ago in East Palestine, Ohio, forcing the evacuation of hundreds of residents and upending life in the town for months, the rail industry pledged to work to become safer, and members of Congress vowed to pass legislation to prevent similar disasters.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sarah Diamond
title: A Pop, Dip and Spin Through the History of ‘Pose’
description: Though the word “pose” is associated with voguing, it is less a part of the vocabulary and more a part of the movement.
content: In 1924, the artist Nancy Cox-McCormack recounted her experience sculpting the bust of Benito Mussolini in an article for The New York Times Magazine, “When Mussolini Poses.” While posing, Mussolini was surrounded by opulent gifts, she wrote, including a music box that “played only the Fascisti marching song.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Johanna Lemola
title: Finland’s Presidential Election, First Since Joining NATO, Heads to Runoff
description: Voting took place as the alliance’s newest member grapples with concerns about potential aggression from its neighbor Russia.
content: Finland’s presidential election is headed for a runoff after no candidate secured a majority in Sunday’s closely watched vote, which came as NATO’s newest member faces the threat of an antagonistic Russia.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Terri Gerstein
title: More People Are Being Classified as Gig Workers. That’s Bad for Everyone.
description: The gig economy is expanding and exploiting more workers.
content: What comes to mind when you think of a mom-and-pop small business: A hardware store? A diner? A family-run clothing store or small-scale supermarket?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rebecca Carballo
title: Maine Town Manager Dies Saving His Son After Both Fall Through Ice
description: Kevin Howell, 51, the town manager in Carmel, Maine, and his 4-year-old son fell through the ice while crossing a pond. He rescued his son, who ran home to get help.
content: The manager of a town in Maine died after saving his 4-year-old son from a frozen pond that they both fell into while on a walk on Friday, officials said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Dave Itzkoff
title: ‘S.N.L.’ Wonders What Men Will Do After Football Season Ends
description: Dakota Johnson hosted and Justin Timberlake was the musical guest in an episode that brought back some old favorites and also offered a few surprises.
content: The Super Bowl may still be two weeks away, but as far as “Saturday Night Live” is concerned, this is your last weekend to experience authentic N.F.L. football.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Callie Holtermann
title: What’s Really Behind the ‘Mob Wife Aesthetic’?
description: A TikTok trend that’s about more than French manicures and furs, the look focuses on conspicuous signifiers of wealth earned outside the rule of law.
content: It’s not every day that Francis Ford Coppola deigns to weigh in on a TikTok trend.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Paulson
title: Obie Awards, Sans Ceremony, Honor ‘Dark Disabled Stories’
description: There was no formal celebration for the newest honorees. Instead, the American Theater Wing presented cash grants to sustain their work.
content: The Obie Awards, a scrappy but venerable annual competition honoring the best theater staged Off and Off Off Broadway, has chosen “Dark Disabled Stories,” Ryan J. Haddad’s autobiographical work inspired by his experiences navigating the city with cerebral palsy, as the best new American play.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maggie Haberman and Kate Christobek
title: At the Defense Table, Trump Uses the Courtroom as a Stage
description: In two civil trials, the former president has showcased his disdain for the legal system and provided a preview of how he might handle himself when any of his four criminal cases go to trial.
content: He shook his head in anger, sitting with his back hunched. He spoke to his lawyers, his words sometimes quite audible to the packed courtroom. He wrote instructions for his defense team that he shoved their way. He walked in late at one point, and at another, while a lawyer suing him was speaking to the jury, he stalked out.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Learning Network
title: What’s Going On in This Picture? | Jan. 29, 2024
description: Look closely at this image, stripped of its caption, and join the moderated conversation about what you and other students see.
content: 1. After looking closely at the image above (or at the full-size image), think about these three questions:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Waldstein
title: Not a Priest, Not a Man, but Ready to Run Fordham
description: Tania Tetlow is the first woman and layperson to lead the Jesuit university in its 182-year history. It’s not the first time she’s done this.
content: Tania Tetlow, the newish president of Fordham University, was in New Orleans, isolating with a case of Covid over winter break, when she learned that Claudine Gay had been forced to resign as Harvard’s president. She did not know all the facts of the case, but it was still a sobering moment.
source.name: The New York Times

author: Alexandra Jacobs
title: A New Martha Graham Biography Is a Study in Grace and Balance
description: Deborah Jowitt’s “Errand Into the Maze” revels in the artistry of the dance legend, while downplaying the messy choices in her marathon career.
content: “Old age is a pain in the neck,” Martha Graham wrote in her 1991 memoir, “Blood Memory.” Death, though, has been good to her.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Wines
title: Arizona G.O.P. Picks New Leader After Scandal Creates a Vacancy
description: Gina Swoboda, a hard-right Trump supporter, was picked to replace Jeff DeWit, who resigned after the release of a recording that appeared to suggest a bribe to Kari Lake.
content: Arizona Republicans chose a new party chair on Saturday, a move that tightened the grip on the state party hierarchy by far-right supporters of former President Donald J. Trump and that came days after a scandal that forced the last chairman to resign.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matthew Mpoke Bigg
title: Ukraine Accuses Defense Company of Embezzling $40 Million
description: The case comes as the Kyiv government tries to emphasize its focus on fighting graft.
content: Ukraine’s intelligence agency said it had exposed a defense company’s $40 million embezzlement scheme, money that had been intended to procure mortar rounds, as the government sought to underline its commitment to fighting corruption at a time when U.S. military aid has stalled.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Katherine Rosman and Gaya Gupta
title: Photographing the Last of the Holocaust Survivors
description: The artist Gillian Laub has created a new photo archive of more than 200 survivors. On Saturday, some of those portraits were projected onto buildings and structures throughout New York City.
content: Rabbi Aliza Erber, 80, stood at the edge of a pier in Lower Manhattan and told those around her to draw closer — and to look out toward the Brooklyn Bridge.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jonathan Weisman and Jazmine Ulloa
title: Haley’s Dilemma: How to Diminish Trump Without Alienating Republican Voters
description: On “Meet the Press,” Nikki Haley said she trusted a jury’s judgment in Donald Trump’s sex-assault defamation case, while she tries to peel away the former president’s supporters.
content: Nikki Haley, searching for a message to dent Donald J. Trump’s appeal with Republican voters, took him to task on Sunday for the $83 million verdict for defaming a woman he was already liable for sexually assaulting, saying she “absolutely” trusted the jury’s judgment for the writer, E. Jean Carroll.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Peter Baker
title: Biden Vows to Retaliate After Strike Against American Forces in Jordan
description: President Biden has carefully calibrated his responses to attacks by Iranian-backed militias since Oct. 7. Now he must decide how far he is willing to go after a drone attack killed three American service members.
content: This was the day that President Biden and his team had feared for more than three months, the day that relatively low-level attacks by Iranian proxy groups on American troops in the Middle East turned deadly and intensified the pressure on the president to respond in kind.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Amanda Holpuch
title: Ring to Stop Allowing Police to Request Videos From Security Cameras
description: Ring, a maker of internet-connected cameras that is owned by Amazon, said the police could no longer ask people to share video recordings using the company’s app, Neighbors.
content: Ring, a home security camera company owned by Amazon, said that it would stop letting police departments request users’ footage in its app amid longstanding concerns from privacy advocates about the company’s relationship with law enforcement.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Corrections: Jan. 28, 2024
description: Corrections that appeared in print on Sunday, Jan. 28, 2024.
content: A picture caption with an article on Jan. 21 about the former boxer Mike Tyson’s move into the cannabis market in New York misstated the year of the bout in which Mr. Tyson bit Evander Holyfield’s ear. As the article correctly notes, it was 1997, not 1987.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Quotation of the Day: $1.7 Million and 3 Years for Bathroom in Bay Area?
description: Quotation of the Day for Sunday, January 28, 2024.
content: “Why isn’t there a toilet here? I just don’t get it. Nobody does.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jeffery C. Mays and Emma G. Fitzsimmons
title: The N.Y.P.D. Pulled Over a City Councilman. Now Both Are Under Fire.
description: Yusef Salaam, one of the Central Park Five, said the officer who stopped him should have explained why. Some officials said Mr. Salaam had used his position to avoid a ticket.
content: Yusef Salaam, the newly elected New York City Council member who was wrongfully convicted in 1990 as a member of the Central Park Five, was in Harlem on Friday night, driving downtown to dinner with his wife and four of his children, when the flashing lights of a police car appeared behind him.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lydia DePillis
title: Private Equity Is Starting to Share With Workers, Without Taking a Financial Hit
description: The buyout giant KKR pioneered a model of granting ownership stakes to employees at portfolio companies. Now it wants the approach to spread.
content: In 2018, Anna-Lisa Miller was working with agricultural cooperatives in Hawaii, helping them reinvest in their communities through shared ownership.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Amelia Nierenberg
title: Monday Briefing: U.S. Service Members Killed in Jordan
description: Also, the UNRWA is in trouble and an antiwar candidate rises in Russia.
content: Three U.S. service members were killed in Jordan yesterday and 25 others were injured in what the U.S. said was a drone strike from an Iran-backed militia. The deaths were the first U.S. military fatalities from hostile fire in the turmoil spilling over from Israel’s war with Hamas in Gaza.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kevin Draper
title: Sexual Assault Claims Against McMahon Shadow a W.W.E. Trying to Move Forward
description: Several high-profile deals have the company well-positioned for years to come, but legal entanglements involving Vince McMahon, its former, longtime leader, are not going away.
content: Cody Rhodes emerged victorious from World Wrestling Entertainment’s “Royal Rumble” on Saturday night, an annual marquee event for the company that culminates in a battle royale match in which 30 wrestlers enter the ring and fight it out until only one remains.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By New York Times Games
title: The Connections Companion
description: In case you need some puzzle help.
content: Good morning, dear connectors. Welcome to today’s Connections forum, where you can give and receive puzzle — and emotional — support.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lauretta Charlton
title: For New Moms in Seoul, 3 Weeks of Pampering and Sleep at a Joriwon
description: Some new mothers say postpartum care centers are the best part of childbirth in South Korea, where fewer people are deciding to have children because of high costs.
content: Four mothers sat quietly in the nursing room around midnight, breastfeeding their newborn babies. As one mother nodded off, her eyelids heavy after giving birth less than two weeks earlier, a nurse came in and whisked her baby away. The exhausted new mom returned to her private room to sleep.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alissa Wilkinson
title: At Sundance, A.I., Psychics and Other Ways of Connecting With the Dead
description: Festival documentaries ranged across the genre map, but several explored the lengths we’ll go to communicate with lost loved ones.
content: Everyone from the academy to streaming services splits cinema into two buckets: movies (comedy, romance, horror, whatever) and documentaries, lumped into one unholy pile. Besides being obviously reductive, the division is false: Nonfiction movies can be comedies or romances or horror or any other genre, and they can create new indescribable genres, too. But American audiences still tend to be fed documentaries of only a few types: true crime stories, cult exposés, hagiographies, and educational disquisitions full of talking heads.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maggie Haberman and Jonathan Swan
title: Key Network of G.O.P. Megadonors to Meet With Trump and Haley Camps
description: Assessing the presidential race, the American Opportunity Alliance has invited representatives from both the Trump and Haley campaigns to make their pitches at a meeting next week.
content: A network of Republican megadonors has invited aides to both Donald J. Trump and Nikki Haley to make presentations at the group’s winter meeting next week, as the wealthy contributors assess the presidential race with just nine months until Election Day.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Vivian Wang, Agnes Chang and Siyi Zhao
title: What It Took Young People in China to Get Their Jobs
description: For many job seekers, the toughest market in years is exacting a physical and emotional toll.
content: For many job seekers, the toughest market in years is exacting a physical and emotional toll.
source.name: The New York Times

title: John Malkovich on (Really) Being John Malkovich
description: “So many people think a lot about this or that,” says the iconic actor. “I just do this or that.”

author: By Nailah Morgan and Arijeta Lajka
title: ‘Two Days of Horror’: Doctor Documents Scene at Nasser Hospital
description: Dr. Ahmed Moghrabi, a surgeon who has worked at Nasser Medical Complex for three years, said that the “pressure is very big” at the hospital as Israeli forces surrounded Khan Younis, Gaza.
